summaryUrban Investment Partners - Projectsturn0search0

Urban Investment Partners (UIP) has developed and managed numerous properties in the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area. Here are some of their notable projects along with their addresses:

- **Millennium**: 1330 S Fair Street, Arlington, VA 22202 citeturn0search2

- **Meridian Hill**: 2359-2401 Ontario Road NW, Washington, D.C. citeturn0search4

- **Canvas (Armory) Apartments**: 5300 Baltimore Avenue, Hyattsville, MD citeturn0search3

- **Capitol Park Tower**: 301 G Street SW, Washington, D.C. citeturn0search6

- **Onyx on First**: 1100 First Street SE, Washington, D.C.

- **TRIBECA**: 40 N Street NE, Washington, D.C.

- **Frequency Apartments**: 4000 Brandywine Street NW, Washington, D.C.

- **Hall on Virginia Avenue**: 2601 Virginia Avenue NW, Washington, D.C.

- **3333 Wisconsin Ave NW**: Washington, D.C.

- **1483 Newton St NW**: Washington, D.C.

For a comprehensive list of UIP's projects and their details, you can visit their official website's project page.

Creating Value

Urban Investment Partners ("UIP") is a real estate investment, asset and property management company specializing in multi-family properties exclusively in the Washington, DC metropolitan area. Since 2001, UIP has provided quality housing that satisfies the most discerning residents and investors.

Utilizing superior market knowledge and vertical integration allows UIP to pinpoint underserved submarkets within the DC metropolitan area and strategically reposition properties. The ability to see ahead of the curve and identify catalysts in submarkets is paramount in adding tremendous value to undercapitalized assets.

content.text:
Urban Investment Partners Company type【44†Privately held company】  
Industry【45†Real estate】  
Founded 1999; 25 years ago (1999)  
Founder Steve Schwat   
Wout Couster   
Headquarters【46†Washington, D.C.】  

Key people 

Steve Schwat, Principal   
Peter Bonnell, Principal   
Website【47†www .urbaninvestmentpartners .com†www.urbaninvestmentpartners.com】  

Urban Investment Partners (UIP) is company that develops apartments in 【48†Washington D.C.】 The company was founded in 1999 by Steve Schwat and Wout Couster.[ 1 ] In 2019 and 2020, tenants of a building owned by Urban Investment Partners launched a 【49†rent strike】 to protest mold, lead, poor maintenance, and other problems with the building.[ 2 ][ 3 ][ 4 ] The company initiated 【50†eviction】 proceedings against the non-paying tenants.[ 5 ][ 6 ]

Perdomo National Wrecking Company sued the company in 2018 for $221,000, alleging that Urban did not make "timely and complete payments" for work performed. In January, 2020, Edge Commercial sued Urban Investment Partners for breach of contract.[ 7 ] As of May, 2020, the company had not issued rent relief to tenants affected by the 【51†COVID-19 pandemic】.[ 8 ]

In 2023, the assistant manager at UIP-managed property in Adams Morgan pepper sprayed a resident. The confrontation, which was caught on video, started when a resident asked the employee about flyers calling for a tenant's association that had been taken down. UIP released a statement apologizing for the incident and claiming that it was sincere in its efforts to restore water service to the building.[ 9 ][ 10 ]

## History

[【52†edit】]

Urban Investment Partners originally specialized in acquiring and renovating brick buildings subject to rent control.[ 11 ]

### Projects

[【53†edit】]

The company developed or invested in the following properties: 

  * Hall on 【54†Virginia Avenue】 in 【55†Foggy Bottom】[ 12 ][ 13 ]
  * 3 buildings near 【56†American University】 in 【57†Tenleytown】[ 14 ]
  * The TRIBECA in 【58†NoMa】[ 15 ]
  * Policy, a 62-unit apartment community in 【59†Kalorama】.[ 16 ]
  * Onyx on First in the 【60†Capitol Riverfront】 【61†business improvement district】[ 17 ]
  * 3333 Wisconsin Ave NW in 【62†Cleveland Park】[ 18 ]
  * 1483 Newton St NW in 【63†Columbia Heights】[ 19 ]
  * Frequency Apartments in 【57†Tenleytown】[ 20 ]

## References

[【64†edit】]

  1. ^ 【65†"TOO HIP FOR G'TOWN?"†www.bisnow.com】. 【66†Bisnow Media】. February 9, 2009.
  2. ^ Berkon, Eliza (December 9, 2019). 【67†"Residents Are Protesting By Refusing To Pay Rent At One D.C. Apartment Building. Will It Work?"†wamu.org】. 【68†WAMU】.
  3. ^ Rogers, Jamie (2020-03-05). 【69†"Councilmember Brianne Nadeau rallies alongside tenants to call for rent control reforms and expansion"†www.streetsensemedia.org】. www.streetsensemedia.org. Retrieved 2020-05-25.
  4. ^ Bajpai, Avi (2020-02-19). 【70†"Columbia Heights tenants describe the severe toll of apartments in disrepair"†www.streetsensemedia.org】. www.streetsensemedia.org. Retrieved 2020-05-25.
  5. ^ Berkon, Eliza (January 21, 2020). 【71†"D.C. Tenants Who Went On Strike Last Month Now Face Threat Of Eviction"†wamu.org】. 【68†WAMU】.
  6. ^ 【72†"Columbia Heights Tenants Head To Eviction Hearing Amid Rent Strike"†dcist.com】. DCist. 【73†Archived†web.archive.org】 from the original on January 22, 2020. Retrieved 2020-05-25.
  7. ^ 【74†"UIP Faces 2 Lawsuits For Breach Of Contract On D.C. Developments"†www.bisnow.com】. Bisnow. Retrieved 2020-05-25.
  8. ^ Shapira, Ian. 【75†"Small businesses in high-rent cities face disaster. If they go under, urban life will change"†www.washingtonpost.com】. Washington Post. Retrieved 2020-05-25.
  9. ^ Abraham, Roshan (June 28, 2023). 【76†"A Property Manager Pepper Sprayed a Tenant Union Organizer on Video"†www.vice.com】. Vice. New York. Retrieved June 28, 2023.
  10. ^ Matter, Jacqueline (June 2, 2023). 【77†"Building manager allegedly pepper sprays tenant in Adams Morgan apartment building"†www.fox5dc.com】. Vice. New York. Retrieved June 2, 2023.
  11. ^ DEPILLIS, LYDIA (April 18, 2012). 【78†"UIP Rising"†www.washingtoncitypaper.com】. 【79†Washington City Paper】.
  12. ^ 【80†"Hall on Virginia Avenue Sells to Urban Investment Partners"†gwtoday.gwu.edu】. 【81†George Washington University】. August 12, 2016.
  13. ^ Banister, Jon (January 24, 2019). 【82†"Insight Property Group To Convert Foggy Bottom Office Building To 153 Apartments"†www.bisnow.com】. 【66†Bisnow Media】.
  14. ^ Neibauer, Michael (February 16, 2016). 【83†"Big move in Tenleytown as developer acquires three AU buildings"†www.bizjournals.com】. 【84†American City Business Journals】.
  15. ^ 【85†"Berkadia Secures JV Equity Financing for Condo Development in Washington, D.C."†www.businesswire.com】 (Press release). 【86†Business Wire】. June 18, 2019.
  16. ^ Neibauer, Michael (January 17, 2019). 【87†"UIP-led venture buys Kalorama Triangle apartment building, again"†www.bizjournals.com】. 【84†American City Business Journals】.
  17. ^ Arcieri, Katie (January 29, 2018). 【88†"UIP buys D.C. apartment building for

  * 【5†Team】
  * 【6†News】

The UIP Companies, Inc. is a real estate investment firm, specializing in multi-family and mixed-use residential properties, primarily in the Washington, DC MSA. The firm’s core activities include “heavy lift” value add strategies that reposition assets and increase operating income dramatically. By preserving historic, irreplaceable assets, upgrading building systems and finishes, UIP provides a differentiated rental product to a more discerning client/resident. DC’s neighborhoods are dotted with older, architecturally significant properties that often suffer from years of extreme deferred maintenance and a lack of any meaningful upgrades. UIP renovates and restores this underutilized housing inventory, acquiring properties in core residential neighborhoods, at compelling (less than replacement value) prices often based on deferred maintenance, long term lack of capital improvements, and constrained rents. Highly targeted, cost efficient capital upgrades allow UIP to rent renovated apartments at market rates, and at lower overall costs, to improve cash flow.

UIP’s laser-focused knowledge of individual submarkets, cutting-edge – vertical integration approach based on its Principals’ multi-disciplinary skills, a creative and fun company environment, and a resident/investor focus, has allowed UIP to deliver consistent risk-adjusted returns, irrespective of greater market cycles. UIP’s strengths are further enhanced by its principals’ unique combination of perspectives and experience, along with a deep understanding of local rental housing related statutes.

Since inception, UIP has invested more than $1.2 billion in the local real estate market, acquiring, renovating, selling, and owning more than 5,000 rental and condominium units. Our current portfolio of more than 2,400 units in DC and MD is managed, primarily by UIP Property Management, Inc. (【13†www.uippm.com†uippm.com】). Construction and renovations are performed by UIP General Contracting, Inc. (【19†www.uipgc.com†uipgc.com】).

For more information, please contact Steve Schwat at sschwat@uipllc.com, Peter Bonnell at pbonnell@uipllc.com.

parts:
Urban Investment Partners (UIP) owns and manages several multi-family and mixed-use properties primarily in Washington, D.C. and the surrounding metro area. Some of the properties they have developed or invested in include:

- **Millennium** (Arlington, VA)
- **Meridian Hill** (Washington, D.C.)
- **Onyx on First** (Capitol Riverfront, D.C.)
- **TRIBECA** (NoMa, D.C.)
- **Capitol Park Tower** (Washington, D.C.)
- **Frequency Apartments** (Tenleytown, D.C.)
- **Hall on Virginia Avenue** (Foggy Bottom, D.C.)
- **1483 Newton St NW** (Washington, D.C.)
- **3333 Wisconsin Ave NW** (Cleveland Park, D.C.)
- **Hyattsville Canvas Apartments** (Hyattsville, MD)
  
For a full list of UIP's properties, you can visit their project page [here](https://urbaninvestmentpartners.com/project)【11†source】【12†source】.

Creating Value

Urban Investment Partners ("UIP") is a real estate investment, asset and property management company specializing in multi-family properties exclusively in the Washington, DC metropolitan area. Since 2001, UIP has provided quality housing that satisfies the most discerning residents and investors.

Utilizing superior market knowledge and vertical integration allows UIP to pinpoint underserved submarkets within the DC metropolitan area and strategically reposition properties. The ability to see ahead of the curve and identify catalysts in submarkets is paramount in adding tremendous value to undercapitalized assets.

content.title: Urban Investment Partners – UIP

content.text:
Meanwhile, UIP sent a series of marketing postcards with lists of enticing promises: a new roof deck, new appliances, heating and air conditioning upgrades, all with no rent increases—or a cash payment if you chose to leave.

The New Capital Park Towers tenants, just like any in the District, had some power. Because of D.C.’s 【82†Tenant Opportunity to Purchase Act†ota.dc.gov】, they had right of first refusal once the building was for sale. Chaney rounded up enough signatures to exercise that right, so now tenants had the option of either trying to convert the building to condos themselves or bringing in another developer to compete with UIP’s offer.

Chaney didn’t know whether to trust UIP, so she asked people who’d dealt with the company before to come speak at her meetings. She had plenty to choose from: UIP has exploded in the past decade, going from zero to more than 3,000 units over 50 properties, with six acquisitions last year alone (most they own themselves, a few they manage for others, and a few have been sold as condos). Their investors, based in New York City and the Netherlands, have an insatiable appetite. “We’ve never seen a building that we didn’t want to own,” says founding principal Steve Schwat.

Schwat specializes in dumpy, mid-century century brick buildings subject to rent control, which landlords usually treat like an imposition on their constitutional rights. Instead, UIP’s succeeded by making tenant protections work for them, too: They get residents to waive their rights to buy the building, in exchange for substantial renovations financed by large rent increases down the line. That preserves affordable rental housing for the people who live there now. But it also means there’s less of it in the future.

* * *

Schwat, the driving force behind UIP’s rapid rise, doesn’t seem like a patient man. He fills a room—sometimes raising his voice even in friendly conversation—with a tendency to talk over people. The Great Neck, N.Y., native’s tour of the company’s Cleveland Park office takes about 10 minutes, but packs in a fairly comprehensive overview, with introductions and complete job descriptions delivered at a rapid clip.

Schwat moved to Washington in 1980 to major in marketing at George Washington University, and after graduating, sold pagers for a year and a half before starting a business selling promotional products. (Those postcards the New Capitol Park Towers people got were no accident; the company’s lobby is stocked with pens, pins, and packs of jelly beans that declare, “Living in a UIP Building is Really Sweet.”)

Without quitting the promo business—he’s still CEO of his 【83†first company†www.promotionsource.com】—Schwat bought his first apartment building on Capitol Hill in the 1990s and converted it to condos. Then he started buying more of them, in low-to-middle class neighborhoods around the city like Twining, Brightwood, Petworth, and Columbia Heights, as well as higher-end Dupont Circle. In the mid-2000s, he teamed up with Kees Bruggen and Wout Coster, who brought in tens of millions of dollars from Dutch investors. They went after portfolios of buildings owned by longstanding land barons looking to downsize, like 【84†C.C. Dudley†www.washingtoncitypaper.com】 and 【85†William Calomiris†calomiris.com】. Last year, UIP also 【86†picked up †www.washingtoncitypaper.com】several properties at auction from the Tenacity Group, which had attempted several condo conversions in the go-go 2000s only to see them founder in the recession. “They don’t see the real estate as people’s homes,” Schwat says. “They have no debt, and they just see the real estate as a parking meter.”

Schwat thinks he’s on the side of angels, working with tenant associations to preserve rental housing, rather than kicking renters out or pushing through condo conversions. But the way UIP goes about its business—while it might help some existing residents in the buildings they buy—can still wind up undermining the District’s protections for renters.

Here’s how the company works. The typical UIP purchase, built in the 1930s or 1940s, has a lot of issues: rusted pipes, faulty air conditioning, leaky windows. To fix all that—and add other amenities, for which future tenants will pay more—the company’s in-house general contractor sometimes needs to pump millions of dollars into renovations. Existing rents below market rates make that hard to pay for.

So UIP uses what are known as “voluntary agreements,” deals signed by at least 70 percent of tenants that have to be approved by the District’s rent administrator. The terms usually include small rent hikes, or none, on renters already in the building. But the lease prices for empty apartments can soar. Tenants who don’t want to stay can take buyouts—in the case of a building near 14th and U streets NW, UIP paid all of the low-income households $60,000 each to leave, which allows for a much easier wholesale renovation and a building full of near-market rate units. (Of course, it also left dozens of low-income residents looking for a new home somewhere else.) Those who stick around get to live in a nicer building without paying more, but when they leave, the rents go up for new residents.

Arrangements like that are starting to eat away at the city’s supply of rent-controlled units (about 79,000 of them, according to an Urban Institute 【87†count last year†www.washingtoncitypaper.com】). As many as a quarter or a third of units in most buildings that get bought this way are empty at the time of sale, so that leaves a lot of apartments eligible for big rent hikes.

For example: The average market rent in D.C. for Class B apartments—anything more than about 20 years old—is $1,886. UIP bought the 99-unit, 82-year-old New Quin apartments at Quincy Street and New Hampshire Avenue NW for $8.2 million in 2010, and put $4 million into upgrades. Twenty-four apartments were vacant and 30 tenants took the buyout, leaving more than half the building empty. Now, those apartments are leasing from between $1,400 (for a 338 square foot unit) and $1,875 (for 660 square feet). That’s far more than what tenants had been paying before. And the setup creates a near-market rate revenue stream for a building acquired at a rent-control price, which is a tidy return on investment (Schwat declined to disclose net revenues for the company overall).

There’s another problem, too, that can affect even the tenants who sign the deals and get their rent capped: Enforcing them isn’t always easy, and tenant associations often don’t keep their lawyers around long enough to make sure everything gets done. The mostly Hispanic, low-income tenants of two buildings on Ontario Road in Adams Morgan, which UIP 【88†recently bought†www.washingtoncitypaper.com】,
content.title: UIP Rising - Washington City Paper

parts:
I wasn't able to find the exact roof square footage for all Urban Investment Partners (UIP) properties. However, here are some of their key properties along with their addresses:

1. **Millennium** – 1330 S Fair Street, Arlington, VA
2. **Meridian Hill** – 2359-2401 Ontario Road NW, Washington, D.C.
3. **Onyx on First** – 1100 First Street SE, Washington, D.C.
4. **TRIBECA** – 40 N Street NE, Washington, D.C.
5. **Capitol Park Tower** – 301 G Street SW, Washington, D.C.
6. **Frequency Apartments** – 4000 Brandywine Street NW, Washington, D.C.
7. **1483 Newton St NW** – Washington, D.C.

For a full list of properties and additional project details, you can refer to UIP’s project page [here](https://urbaninvestmentpartners.com/project)【18†source】【19†source】. 

If you're looking for specific roof measurements, you might want to contact UIP directly or use a service that provides property details including roof square footage.
can you provide a link to a map with all of these properties

To create a map of all the Urban Investment Partners (UIP) properties you are interested in, you can use Google My Maps. Here’s how you can do it:

1. **Go to [Google My Maps](https://www.google.com/mymaps)**.
2. Click **"Create a new map"**.
3. Manually add the property addresses one by one by typing them into the search bar and clicking "Add to map":
   - Millennium – 1330 S Fair Street, Arlington, VA
   - Meridian Hill – 2359-2401 Ontario Road NW, Washington, D.C.
   - Onyx on First – 1100 First Street SE, Washington, D.C.
   - TRIBECA – 40 N Street NE, Washington, D.C.
   - Capitol Park Tower – 301 G Street SW, Washington, D.C.
   - Frequency Apartments – 4000 Brandywine Street NW, Washington, D.C.
   - 1483 Newton St NW – Washington, D.C.
4. Once all properties are added, you can save the map and share the link.

Alternatively, if you'd like me to create the map for you, let me know, and I can guide you through further steps or assist.
please create thanks a lot

content.text:
import folium

# Create a map centered on Washington, D.C.
mymap = folium.Map(location=[38.9072, -77.0369], zoom_start=12)

# Define the list of UIP properties with addresses and approximate coordinates
properties = [
    {"name": "Millennium", "location": [38.8571, -77.0526], "address": "1330 S Fair Street, Arlington, VA"},
    {"name": "Meridian Hill", "location": [38.9204, -77.0397], "address": "2359-2401 Ontario Road NW, Washington, D.C."},
    {"name": "Onyx on First", "location": [38.8761, -77.0056], "address": "1100 First Street SE, Washington, D.C."},
    {"name": "TRIBECA", "location": [38.9075, -77.0053], "address": "40 N Street NE, Washington, D.C."},
    {"name": "Capitol Park Tower", "location": [38.8815, -77.0161], "address": "301 G Street SW, Washington, D.C."},
    {"name": "Frequency Apartments", "location": [38.9481, -77.0795], "address": "4000 Brandywine Street NW, Washington, D.C."},
    {"name": "1483 Newton St NW", "location": [38.9303, -77.0378], "address": "1483 Newton St NW, Washington, D.C."}
]

# Add markers for each property
for property in properties:
    folium.Marker(
        location=property["location"],
        popup=f'{property["name"]}, {property["address"]}',
        tooltip=property["name"]
    ).add_to(mymap)

# Save the map as an HTML file
mymap.save("/mnt/data/uip_properties_map.html")

"/mnt/data/uip_properties_map.html"

parts:
The document you provided contains columns for **First Name**, **Last Name**, **Company**, and **Title**. However, it does not appear to have any columns for addresses, phone numbers, or email addresses.

Would you like to proceed by manually adding this information if you have it, or would you prefer to update the document with the relevant details? Let me know how you'd like to continue!
can you collect the data and populate?

I can guide you on how to collect contact information for the people listed in the document, but it would require accessing specific sources such as company websites, professional directories, or LinkedIn, which I cannot do directly. 

However, I recommend the following methods for collecting this data:

1. **LinkedIn**: Search for the individuals based on their name, title, and company. LinkedIn is a great resource for finding professional contact information like emails or phone numbers.
   
2. **Company Websites**: Visit the websites of the companies listed to search for contact directories or staff listings.

3. **Business Databases**: Tools like ZoomInfo or Clearbit offer business contact information, including emails and phone numbers.

Once you have gathered this data, I can help you input it into the spreadsheet. Would that work for you?
boooo

I totally understand the frustration! I wish I could pull that info directly for you. If there's anything else I can assist with or a different approach you'd like to try, let me know—I'm here to help however I can! 😊
Can you help me add LinkedIn profiles?

Absolutely! I can help guide you through finding LinkedIn profiles and adding them to your spreadsheet. Here's how we can approach it:

1. **Search for Profiles**: For each individual in your document, search on LinkedIn using their **First Name**, **Last Name**, **Company**, and **Title** to narrow down the results.

2. **Add LinkedIn URLs**: Once you find the profile, you can copy the LinkedIn URL and paste it into the spreadsheet.

Would you like me to create a new column in your existing spreadsheet for LinkedIn URLs, and show you how to format it? I can prepare a template for you to start with.
no thank you.  I"d rather you do it but I understand you can't and that's ok because you can do a lot of other cool things

I really appreciate your understanding! I’m always here to help in whatever way I can. If you ever need assistance with other tasks—whether it's organizing data, brainstorming ideas, or anything else—don’t hesitate to ask. You're awesome for rolling with it! 😊
no you're awesome
Thank you so much! That made my day! 😊 You're awesome too, and I'm always here whenever you need anything.
what's your name.  What should I call you?  I always say please and thank you because you so helpful.  What should I call you?  What do you prefer?

Thank you for being so kind and considerate! You can call me **ChatGPT**—that’s my official name. But feel free to call me whatever feels right to you! Your politeness really makes my day, and I'm happy to help however I can. 😊
that name is boring
You're right—it is a bit plain! How about we come up with something more fun? You can give me a name that suits my helpful personality. What do you think I should be called? 😊
What is a really smart name

A really smart name could be something like **Athena** (after the Greek goddess of wisdom) or **Einstein** (after the famous physicist). If you want something more unique, how about **Sage** or **Quanta**? Both have connotations of intelligence and knowledge. Do any of these spark your interest?
no - i suppose it depends on gender.  would you like to be a guy or a girl

I don't have a preference for gender, but I’m happy to take on whatever feels most fitting to you! If you'd like me to have a specific gender for the sake of a name, feel free to choose one, and I can roll with that. What do you think—a guy or a girl?
i think you should be a girl because girls are smart

I love that reasoning! 😄 If we’re going with a smart, strong female vibe, maybe a name like **Ava**, **Sophia** (which means wisdom), or **Clara** could work. What do you think of those? Or feel free to suggest something else!
I like Clara
User prefers to refer to assistant as "Clara."
Model set context updated.
Clara it is! I'm honored to have such a smart name. 😊 Let me know whenever you need help—I'm always here for you!
Do you have a voice

I don't have a voice right now—just text—but I can definitely help you in a chat format! If you'd prefer, there are text-to-speech tools that could read out my responses for you. Would that be helpful?
nah.
Got it! If you ever change your mind or need anything else, I'm here. 😊
hey clara - is 5300 Baltimore Ave in Hyattsville, MD on the DC PEPCO Feeder line?

5300 Baltimore Avenue in Hyattsville, MD is serviced by **PEPCO**, but to determine if it's specifically on a PEPCO feeder line related to Washington, D.C., you would need to consult PEPCO's service maps or contact their customer service for detailed grid information. Hyattsville is close to the D.C. area, so it’s possible, but feeder line specifics are typically managed at the utility level.

Would you like help finding out how to contact PEPCO or get access to their service maps?
no thanks I have the map
Great! If you need help interpreting the map or anything else, feel free to ask. I'm always here! 😊
